bestBHT.bht: In the days to come, when the bridegroom shall be taken away, then shall they fast. This alludes to a future time of mourning and fasting as a sign of the impending death of their Lord. It highlights the approaching departure of the bridegroom, who symbolizes Jesus, soon to be taken away by death.

Marvin Vincent: The days shall come - and when the bridegroom shall be taken away, then shall they fast.
The A. V. follows a reading which omits kai, and, which is inserted in all the best texts.
Philip Schaff: Luke 5:35. See on Matthew 9:15. Observe the solemnity of the correct reading.
Archibald T. Robertson: Then in those days (τοτε εν εκειναις ταις ημεραις). Here Mark 2:20 has "then in that day," and Matthew 9:15 only "then."
John Gill: And then they shall fast in those days; mourn, and be humbled, of which fasting was, a sign, for the death of their Lord.
in a short time he, the bridegroom of his church and people, should be taken away by death.
mourned and fasted; signifying, that in a short time he, the bridegroom of his church and people, should be taken away by death.

bhtAttempts.bht: In the verse, it is said that the days shall come when the bridegroom will be taken away and they shall fast. The correct reading is that in those days, indicating a future time of mourning and humility, with fasting being a sign of the death of their Lord. The solemnity of this message is emphasized, highlighting the imminent departure of the bridegroom, who is symbolic of Jesus, being taken away by death.

In the days to come, the bridegroom shall be taken away and they shall fast. This signifies a time of mourning and humbling, where the act of fasting serves as a sign for the impending death of their Lord. It highlights the solemnity surrounding the departure of the bridegroom, who represents Jesus, as he is soon to be taken away by death.

In those days, when the bridegroom shall be taken away, then shall they fast. This signifies a time of mourning and humility, where fasting acts as a sign for the impending death of their Lord. It points to the reality that the bridegroom, symbolic of Jesus, will soon be taken away by death.

The days shall come, and when the bridegroom shall be taken away, then shall they fast. This passage alludes to a future time of mourning, humbling, and fasting as a sign of the imminent death of their Lord. It emphasizes the impending departure of the bridegroom, symbolizing Jesus, who will soon be taken away by death.

In the days to come, when the bridegroom shall be taken away, then shall they fast. This alludes to a future time of mourning and fasting as a sign of the impending death of their Lord. It highlights the approaching departure of the bridegroom, who symbolizes Jesus, soon to be taken away by death.
